case_name: Chintamanrao and Kantilal v. the respondent

facts.text: Messrs. Brijlal Manilal and Company is a bidi factory situated in Sagar.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Brijlal Manilal and Company is a bidi factory situated in Sagar. The 1st Appellant, Chintamanrao, is the Managing-Partner of the firm while the 2nd appellant, Kantilal, is its active Manager.

facts.text: The 1st Appellant, Chintamanrao, is the Managing-Partner of the firm.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st Appellant, Chintamanrao, is the Managing-Partner of the firm while the 2nd appellant, Kantilal, is its active Manager. The Company manufactures bidis.

facts.text: The 2nd appellant, Kantilal, is the active Manager of the firm.

anchor.surface_text: while the 2nd appellant, Kantilal, is its active Manager. The Company manufactures bidis. The process of manufacture, so far as is relevant to the question raised, is carried out in two stages.

facts.text: The management enters into a contract with independent contractors, known as Sattedars, for the supply of bidis locally.

anchor.surface_text: The first stage The management enters into a contract with independent contractors, known as Sattedars, for the supply of bidis locally. The documents embodying the terms of the contract entered into by the Sattedars were not produced in the case.

facts.text: The terms of the contract are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: But the terms of the contract are not in dispute. The Management supplies tobacco to the Sattedars and in some cases bidi leaves.

facts.text: The Management supplies tobacco to the Sattedars and in some cases bidi leaves.

anchor.surface_text: The Management supplies tobacco to the Sattedars and in some cases bidi leaves. Some of the Sattedars maintain a small factory where they get bidis manufactured by engaging coolies.

facts.text: After bidis are rolled the Sattedars collect the bidis so manufactured and take them to the factory directly or through coolies where they are sorted and checked by the workers in the factory.

anchor.surface_text: After bidis are rolled in the Sattedars collect the bidis so manufactured and take them to the factory directly or through coolies where they are sorted and checked by the workers in, the factory.

facts.text: The second stage of the process of the manufacture begins in the factory and is carried out exclusively by the labourers employed in the factory.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the second stage of the process of the manufacture begins in the factory. It is carried out exclusively by the labourers employed in the factory.

facts.text: On December 9, 1952, Sri B. V. Desai, the Inspector of Factories, Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur, visited the factory at 5-30 p. m.

anchor.surface_text: On December 9, 1952, Sri B. V. Desai, the Inspector of Factories, Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur, visited the factory at 5-30 p. m. At the time of his inspection he found the following persons in the factory

facts.text: At the time of inspection, the Inspector found Pirbaksha son of Amir, Abdul Sagir son of Sk. Alam, Deviprasad son of Uddam, Ramshankar son of Mulchand, Gopal son of Mulchand, Nirpat son of Bhagirath, Rameband son of Gyan, Gotiram son of Lila, Basodi son of Gulu in the factory.

anchor.surface_text: Pirbaksha, son of Amir. Abdul Sagir, son of Sk. Alam. Deviprasad, son of Uddam. Ramshankar, son of Mulchand. Gopal, son of Mulchand. Nirpat, son of Bhagirath. Rameband, son of Gyan. Gotiram, son of Lila. Basodi, son of Gulu,

facts.text: Of the aforesaid persons, Deviprasad, Nirpat and Gotiram are Sattedars and the rest are coolies employed by the Sattedars.

anchor.surface_text: Of the aforesaid persons, Deviprasad, Nirpat and Gotiram are Sattedars and the rest are coolies employed by the Sattedars. The Inspector found the first seven persons sorting out bidis

facts.text: The Inspector found the first seven persons sorting out bidis and packing them into bundles of 10 and 25 in the premises and the last two bringing the bidis to the room in jali for warming.

anchor.surface_text: The Inspector found the first seven persons sorting out bidis and packing them into bundles of 10 and 25 in the premises and the last two bringing the bidis to the room in jali for warming.

facts.text: The said facts are practically admitted by some of the aforesaid persons, who gave evidence in the case.

anchor.surface_text: The said facts are practically admitted by some of the aforesaid persons, who gave evidence in the case, and they explained that they came to the factory on that day for delivering the bidis manufactured by them to the factory.

facts.text: Thereafter the Chief Inspector of Factories filed a complaint in the Court of the Judge-Magistrate, Sagar, against the appellants for violation of the provisions of ss. 62 and 63 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Chief Inspector of Factories filed a complaint in the Court of the Judge-Magistrate, Sagar, against the appellants for violation of the provisions of ss. 62 and 63 of the Act, under the former for failure to maintain the register of adult workers

facts.text: The Judge-Magistrate, Sagar, held that the appellants contravened the provisions of ss. 62 and 63 and convicted them under s. 92 of the Act and directed them to pay a fine of Rs. 50 and Rs. 25 respectively on August 5, 1953 in Criminal Case No. 146 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Judge-Magistrate, Sagar, held that the appellants contravened the provisions of the aforesaid sections and on that finding convicted them under s. 92 of the Act and directed them to pay a fine of Rs. 50 and Rs. 25 respectively.

facts.text: On appeal the Second Additional Sessions Judge, Sagar, confirmed the conviction of the 2nd appellant for contravening ss. 62 and 63 but set aside that of the 1st appellant in regard to s. 62 but confirmed for s. 63 on March 8, 1954 in Criminal Appeal No. 368 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Second Additional Sessions Judge, Sagar, confirmed the conviction of the 2nd appellant for contravening the provisions of ss. 62 and 63 but set aside that of the 1st appellant in regard to s. 62 but confirmed the conviction for contravening s. 63 of the Act.

facts.text: The Revision Petition filed by the appellants in the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur was dismissed on September 16, 1954 in Criminal Revision No. 295 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Revision Petition filed by the appellants in the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur was dismissed. As aforesaid with Special Leave of this Court, this appeal was filed against the Order of the High Court.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: As aforesaid with Special Leave of this Court, this appeal was filed against the Order of the High Court.

facts.text: Admittedly the names of the 9 persons were not entered in the register of adult workers maintained by the factory.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly the names of the 9 persons, stated supra, were not entered in the register of adult workers maintained by the factory.

facts.text: Sattedars or their coolies neither work in the appellants factory nor are they subject to the supervision or control of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: He  Sattedar  or his coolies neither work in the appellants factory nor are they subject to the supervision or control of the appellants.

facts.text: The coolies or the third parties to whom the work of making of bidis is entrusted by the Sattedars are employed by the Sattedars and are paid by them.

anchor.surface_text: The coolies or the third parties, to whom the work of making of bidis is entrusted by the Sattedars, are employed by the Sattedars and are paid by them.

facts.text: None of them works in the factory though they bring bidis to the factory for delivery.

anchor.surface_text: None of them works in the factory though they bring bidis to the factory for delivery in accordance with the terms of the contract.

facts.text: The factory employs workers who are under the direct control and supervision of the factory management and who attend to the second part of the process of manufacture.

anchor.surface_text: It may also be pointed out that the factory employs workers who are under the direct control and supervision of the factory management and who attend to the second part of the process of manufacture described above.

facts.text: The persons found came to the factory on that day for delivering the bidis manufactured by them to the factory.

anchor.surface_text: and they explained that they came to the factory on that day for delivering the bidis manufactured by them to the factory.

facts.text: The court holds that Sattedars are independent contractors, not workers under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the Sattedars in this case were not employed by the management as workers but were only independent contractors
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 16 1954, of the former Nagpur High Court in Criminal Revision No. 295 of 1954,

issues.text: the question of construction of some of the provisions of the Factories Act

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by Special Leave is directed against the Order of the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur and raises the question of construction of some of the provisions of the Factories Act  LXIII of 1948   hereinafter referred to as the Act . Before posing the questions raised it would be convenient and useful at the outset to state the facts

arguments.claim: A Sattedar is an independent contractor who undertakes to do a specific job of work without submitting to control, and neither he nor his employee is a worker under s. 2(1) of the Act, so no duty to comply with ss. 62 or 63

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants contends that a Sattedar is an independent contractor, who undertakes to do a specific job of work for other persons without submitting himself to their control, and that he or his employee is not a worker within the definition of s. 2 (1 ) of the Act and therefore the appellants are not under duty to comply with the conditions of ss. 62 or 63 in respect of them.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: k for other persons, without submitting himself to their companytrol in respect to the det

arguments.court_reasoning: Sattedars lack control and supervision by management; independent contractors per control test and facts

arguments.claim: Definition of worker is comprehensive enough to include all persons who work in the factory, whether employed by the factory or not

anchor.surface_text: Whereas the learned Counsel for the State argues that the definition of the word worker is comprehensive enough to take in all persons who work in the factory, whether employed by the factory or not.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f the Act. No adult worker shall be required or allowed to work in any such 1346 factory otherwise than in accordance with the numberice of periods of

arguments.court_reasoning: Definition requires employment relation via contract with control and supervision

arguments.court_reasoning: Persons not workers under the Act

arguments.claim: Worker definition requires employment involving employer, employee, and contract of service

anchor.surface_text: Worker is defined to mean a person employed, directly or through any agency [...] The concept of employment involves three ingredients : (1) employer (2) employee and (3) the contract of employment.

arguments.claim: Distinction between contractor (contract for service) and workman (contract of service); identifying mark is control over details

anchor.surface_text: There is a well understood distinction between a contractor and a workman and between contract for service and contract of service. [...] The identifying mark of the latter is that he should be under the control and supervision of the employer in respect of the details of the work.

arguments.claim: Control test determines master-servant relationship; applied from Dharangadhara Chemical Works

anchor.surface_text: The test which is uniformly applied [...] This Court in Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra [...] the prima facie test for the determination of the relationship between master and servant is the existence of the right in the master to supervise and control the work done by the servant

arguments.claim: Sattedars not workers as no control by management over manner of work; independent contractors

anchor.surface_text: If the test be applied, it is not possible to hold that Sattedars [...] are workers within the meaning of the definition under the Act. [...] He is not under the control of the factory management and he can manufacture bidis wherever he pleases.

arguments.claim: Coolies employed by Sattedars not workers; no direct or agency employment by management, no privity

anchor.surface_text: If the Sattedars [...] were not workers [...] can it be said that the other persons, who were coolies employed by the Sattedars [...] were workers [...] Admittedly the coolies were not employed by the management there was no privity of contract between them and the management.

arguments.claim: Scheme of Chapter VI (ss.51-63) indicates workers under direct management control and supervision

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the aforesaid provisions indicates that the workmen in the factory are under the direct supervision and control of the management. [...] The management obviously cannot fix the working hours [...] if the persons like the Sattedars [...] are workers within the meaning of the Act.

arguments.claim: Provincial Government v. Robinson distinguished: no contention on employment relation raised

anchor.surface_text: There is a conflict of decisions [...] A Divisional Bench of the Nagpur High Court in Provincial Government [...] The question was whether the employees of an independent contractor were workers [...] no contention was raised [...] that the persons found [...] were not the employees

arguments.claim: State v. Jiwabhai dissented: 'employed' does not mean merely engaged in activity without contract

anchor.surface_text: Another Bench of the Nagpur High Court in The State v. Jiwabhai gave a wide connotation to the word employed [...] If the learned Judges meant [...] irrespective of whether there was any contract of employment [...] we should express our respectful dissent

arguments.claim: State v. Shri Krishna Prasad consistent with interpretation that employment requires contract

anchor.surface_text: The decision in State v. Shri Krishna Prasad [...] need not be considered in detail as the learned Judges therein accepted the same interpretation [...] and came to the conclusion, on the facts of that case, that the persons therein were workers

arguments.claim: Decision not a general proposition that Sattedars never workers; depends on contract terms

anchor.surface_text: Our decision is not intended to lay down a general proposition that under no circumstances a Sattedar can be considered to be a worker [...] Whether a particular person [...] is a worker or not under the Act depends upon the terms of the contract

arguments.qualifiers: confined to facts of this case

holdings.text: the Sattedars in this case were not employed by the management as workers but were only independent contractors who performed their part of the contract by making bidis and delivering them at the factory.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the Sattedars in this case were not employed by the management as workers but were only independent contractors who performed their part of the contract by making bidis and delivering them at the factory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sattedars undertake to supply bidis independently without control or supervision by factory management over manner of manufacture; applied control test from Dharangadhara precedent to s.2(1) definition.

holdings.text: coolies employed by the Sattedars are not workers within the meaning of the definition in the Act

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that coolies employed by the Sattedars are not workers within the meaning of the definition in the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Coolies employed by Sattedars, not by management directly or through agency; no privity of contract with management.

holdings.text: neither the Sattedars nor the coolies found by the Inspector to be working in the factory were workers, as they were not employed by the factory

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that neither the Sattedars nor the coolies found by the Inspector to be working in the factory were workers, as they were not employed by the factory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Neither group qualifies as 'worker' under s.2(1) due to absence of employment relationship via control test and agency.

holdings.text: the non-inclusion of their names in the register of adult workers or the absence of any entries in regard to them in the said register would not constitute an offence under s. 92 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: As they were not workers, the non-inclusion of their names in the register of adult workers or the absence of any entries in regard to them in the said register would not constitute an offence under s. 92 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No duty under ss.62/63 arises absent 'workers'; no contravention hence no penalty under s.92.

holdings.text: Our decision is not intended to lay down a general proposition that under no circumstances a Sattedar can be considered to be a worker within the meaning of its definition in the Act

anchor.surface_text: Our decision is not intended to lay down a general proposition that under no circumstances a Sattedar can be considered to be a worker within the meaning of its definition in the Act. Whether a particular person...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ruling confined to facts and contract terms; depends on specific agreements whether Sattedar is worker.

holdings.text: we allow the appeal and set aside the convictions of the appellants

anchor.surface_text: In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the convictions of the appellants under

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts erred in holding persons as workers and convicting for ss.62/63/92 violations.

precedents.cited_proposition: Test for master-servant relationship is existence of right of control over manner of work; prima facie test is right to supervise and control the work not only what work but manner of doing it
precedents.cited_holding: The proper test is whether or not the hirer had authority to control the manner of execution of the act in question.
